newsitem.title: USA: NYC mayor says close to compromise on city budget.
newsitem.headline: NYC mayor says close to compromise on city budget.

text.p: As New York City officials neared an accord on the fiscal year 1998 budget, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani said Wednesday that he was close to a compromise with the City Council over its proposal for job-inducing tax cuts.

"I think there are always grounds for a compromise, and I think we have one," Giuliani said when asked about the tax break, one of the sticking points in the budget negotiations. "But let's wait until the end of the day or tomorrow."

City Council officials said they expected an agreement on the budget, which takes effect July 1, to be announced Wednesday. City officials are looking at June 10 as day a budget accord could be completed.

Giuliani had earlier resisted Council Speaker Peter Vallone's proposal to grant $40 million in tax breaks to "emerging" industries such as software development and biotechnology. But officials said he was willing to accept a broader plan aimed at spurring jobs.

Officials involved in the negotiations said the mayor also was prepared to accept a City Council proposal to reduce the unincorporated business tax (UBT) by offering credit against the personal income tax. The officials said the mayor was willing to accept a figure close to the $75 million UBT reduction the City Council had proposed. --U.S. Municipal Desk, 212-859-1650
